member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer
member.summary: Instances of this class provide access to the accelerometer. You may use this class to register a callback function which will be passed accelerometer data at periodic intervals.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Callback(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Internal callback function registered with 'C' layer. This callback marshals the data and call the C# event.
member.param: A pointer to a 'C' data structure

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor. Provides access to the accelerometer object.
member.remarks: Will throw an exception if hardware is not supported.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Finalize
member.summary: Finalize. This destructor will run only if the Dispose method does not get called.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Dispose
member.summary: Implementation for IDisposable interface

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Dispose(bool disposing) executes in two distinct scenarios. If disposing equals true, the method has been called directly or indirectly by a user's code. Managed and unmanaged resources can be disposed. If disposing equals false, the method has been called by the runtime from inside the finalizer and you should not reference other objects. Only unmanaged resources can be disposed.
member.param: true if called from user code

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.ReadAcceleration
member.summary: This function can be used get a single data reading. If you need multiple data readings then you should register a callback function instead.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.ConvertToScreenAxes(PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Acceleration@)
member.summary: Converts axes from absolute coordinates (a fixed system regardless of how the device is being held) to screen coordinates (used in the windowing system, and can change if the screen is rotated). For example, if the screen is changed from portrait to landscape mode, values reported by the sensor remain the same, but the application window now has different X and Y axes to work with when painting its content. An application can call this routine to convert from the sensor's absolute axes into the windowing system's current axes.

member.name: E:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.AccelerometerEvent
member.summary: Accelerometer data event.
member.remarks: Data arrives very fast. Don't try to updated the screen on every event.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Acceleration
member.summary: Instances of this object hold the accelerometer data. Lying flat on a desk, z should be 1 and x and y should be zero. Sitting upright (i.e. in a dock), x should be 1 and y and z should be zero. Lying on edge with the keyboard to the right, y should be 1 and x and z should be zero.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Acceleration.reserved
member.summary: reserved

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Acceleration.tickCountMs
member.summary: System tick count when reading was taken

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Acceleration.x
member.summary: acceleration in the x direction. Measured in Gs. i.e. gravity = 1G

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Acceleration.y
member.summary: acceleration in the y direction.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.Acceleration.z
member.summary: acceleration in the z direction.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.AccelerometerEventArgs
member.summary: This class defines acceleration event data.

member.summary: Acceleration data

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Accelerometer.AccelerometerHandler
member.summary: Delegate for acceleration data handling

member.summary: Internal callback function registered with 'C' layer. This callback marshals the data and call the C# event.

member.summary: Implementation for IDisposable interface

member.summary: Dispose(bool disposing) executes in two distinct scenarios. If disposing equals true, the method has been called directly or indirectly by a user's code. Managed and unmanaged resources can be disposed. If disposing equals false, the method has been called by the runtime from inside the finalizer and you should not reference other objects. Only unmanaged resources can be disposed.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.ReadOrientation
member.summary: This function can be used get a single data reading. If you need multiple data readings then you should register a callback function instead.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.ConvertToScreenAxes(PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.OrientationData@)
member.summary: Converts heading, pitch, and roll from absolute coordinates (a fixed system regardless of how the device is being held) to screen coordinates (used in the windowing system, and can change if the screen is rotated). For example, if the screen is changed from portrait to landscape mode, values reported by the sensor remain the same, but the application window now has different X and Y axes to work with when painting its content. An application can call this routine to convert from the sensor's absolute axes into the windowing system's current axes. Value units remain the same, but the heading may change by a multiple of 90Â° and the pitch and roll values may be swapped, and may change sign.
member.param: the orientation data to be converted

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.LaunchMagnetometerRecalibration
member.summary: Launches the process for recalibrating the magnetometer, something that must be done occasionally in order to get accurate heading reports. Recalibration requires the user to tilt and rotate the device. When reported heading accuracy is NeedsCalibration, this is the routine to call to perform that calibration.

member.name: E:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.DeviceOrientationEvent
member.summary: Device orientation data event.
member.remarks: Data arrives very fast. Don't try to updated the screen on every event.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.OrientationData
member.summary: Instances of this object hold the device orientation data.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.OrientationData.reserved
member.summary: reserved

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.OrientationData.tickCountMs
member.summary: System tick count when reading was taken

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.OrientationData.headingDegrees
member.summary: Direction pointed to by a line drawn parallel to the screen, from its bottom to its top (in the default screen orientation), as best as it can be determined. 0=North, 90=East, 180=South, 270=West. If the AdjustForLocation property is true and the current location is known (for example from GPS), the heading will be relative to the geographic north pole. Otherwise it is relative to the magnetic north pole. Please note the difference between device heading (which way the device is pointing, reported here) and device course (which way the device is moving, reported by the GPS).

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.OrientationData.locationAdjusted
member.summary: magnetic north (0) vs geographic north (1).

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.OrientationData.headingAccuracy
member.summary: Accuracy of orientation information. Not supported yet. (as of 7515 release 1)

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.OrientationData.pitchDegrees
member.summary: Pitch of the device. Zero indicates no pitch, as if sitting flat on a level surface, screen side up. Positive values indicate upward tilt, with the far end of the device higher, and the near end lower. Range -180 to +179.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.OrientationData.rollDegrees
member.summary: Roll of the device. Zero indicates no roll, as if sitting flat on a level surface, screen side up. Positive values indicate clockwise tilt, with the right side of the device lower, and the left side higher. Range -180 to +179.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.HeadingAccuracy
member.summary: Heading accuracy indication.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.HeadingAccuracy.High
member.summary: High

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.HeadingAccuracy.Medium
member.summary: Medium

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.HeadingAccuracy.Low
member.summary: Low

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.HeadingAccuracy.NeedsCalibration
member.summary: Compass needs to be calibrated

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.DeviceOrientation.HeadingAccuracy.Unavailable
member.summary: No heading data available ( Device may not have a compass )

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Runtime.InteropServices.Marshalling.BasicTypeArrayToArrayList(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Convert an unmanaged array of basic types (int, char, etc) to an array list.
member.remarks: I only needed to convert "normal" ints. If you need to support other types you will have to add them yourself. This is similar to ByteToArrayList, but works for basic types such as int.
member.param: A byte array containing the data
size of each item in the byte array

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope
member.summary: Instances of this class provide access to the gyroscope, a sensor device providing readings of how the device is being physically rotated. You may use this class to register a callback function which will be passed gyroscope data at periodic intervals.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.Callback(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Internal callback function registered with 'C' layer. This callback marshals the data and call the C# event.
member.param: A pointer to a 'C' data structure

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor. Provides access to the gyroscope object.
member.remarks: Will throw an exception if hardware is not supported.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.Finalize
member.summary: Finalize. This destructor will run only if the Dispose method does not get called.

member.summary: Implementation for IDisposable interface

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Dispose(bool disposing) executes in two distinct scenarios. If disposing equals true, the method has been called directly or indirectly by a user's code. Managed and unmanaged resources can be disposed. If disposing equals false, the method has been called by the runtime from inside the finalizer and you should not reference other objects. Only unmanaged resources can be disposed.
member.param: true if called from user code

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.ReadData
member.summary: This function can be used get a single data reading. If you need multiple data readings then you should register a callback function instead.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.ConvertToScreenAxes(PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.AngularVelocity@)
member.summary: Converts X and Y values from absolute coordinates (a fixed system regardless of how the device is being held) to screen coordinates (used in the windowing system, and can change if the screen is rotated). For example, if the screen is changed from portrait to landscape mode, values reported by the sensor remain the same, but the application window now has different X and Y axes to work with when painting its content. An application can call this routine to convert from the sensor's absolute axes into the windowing system's current axes. Value units remain the same, but X and Y values may be swapped, and may change sign.

member.name: E:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.GyroscopeEvent
member.summary: Gyroscope data event.
member.remarks: Data arrives very fast. Don't try to updated the screen on every event.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.AngularVelocity
member.summary: Angular velocity of the device, which indicates how the device is rotating. The three axes are the same as used in the device orientation and accelerometer, with X and Y axes parallel to the screen, X towards the right and Y towards the top (in the default screen orientation), and the Z axis perpendicular to the screen towards the viewer. Rotation directions follow the right-hand rule: With your right thumb pointing from the origin along the axis in the positive direction, the remaining fingers when curled point in the positive rotation direction.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.AngularVelocity.reserved
member.summary: reserved

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.AngularVelocity.tickCountMs
member.summary: System tick count when reading was taken

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.AngularVelocity.x
member.summary: Angular velocity around the X-axis in degrees per second. Positive values indicate increasing pitch, with the top of the screen moving up and towards the user.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.AngularVelocity.y
member.summary: Angular velocity around the Y-axis in degrees per second. Positive values indicate increasing roll, with the left side of the device moving up and towards the right.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.AngularVelocity.z
member.summary: Angular velocity around the Z-axis in degrees per second. Positive values indicate counter-clockwise rotation of the screen.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.GyroscopeEventArgs
member.summary: This class defines gyroscope event data.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.GyroscopeEventArgs.data
member.summary: AngularVelocity data

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Sensors.Gyroscope.GyroscopeHandler
member.summary: Delegate for gyroscope data handling
